category.term: 527~Plants and Animals~Postmedia Network Inc.~Warren Spicer~Stuart Derdeyn
category.label: InformQString

content.div:
Plants and Animals

The End of That

(Secret City Records)

If La La Land, the 2010 sophomore disc by Plants and Animals, was mostly dense, angular epic rock with moments of tightly constructed pop trying to break through, The End of That reverses that balance.

On its third -- and best -- album, the group has not exactly abandoned its need to stretch out. You can hear it in the Blue Jay Way drone of the song "2010," which opens Side B (even the CD is, on paper, divided into two sides) and in the album closer, "Runaways," a stormy, bombastic piece that atypically eschews melody in favour of atmosphere but still sounds compelling.

But the real good news about The End of That is that the songs, most of which stay in the three- and four-minute range, are musically economical and centred on melody. The disc's most defining sound is Warren Spicer's vigorous acoustic guitar propelling the songs, with Nicolas Basque's chiming electric guitar phrases on top and a natural drum sound from Matthew Woodley, which anchors everything without needlessly drawing attention to itself.

The immediately memorable title track is a perfect example. Built around a simple three-chord progression, with a catchy lead guitar phrase that points to India via Haight-Ashbury in 1967, Spicer, who wrote all the album's lyrics, looks with hope toward a future no longer defined by self-destructive behaviour.

But to call this the group's pop album would be misleading. "Crisis!" is made up of two distinct parts: a rock-riff-based screamer and a second section that builds with the unexplainable familiarity of a vintage David Bowie buried treasure. In its crazy-like-a-fox anarchy, the track puts the album in Wilco territory.

The album's lead-off single, "Lightshow," shows Plants and Animals cautiously setting foot in Arcade Fire territory before they scratch the idea with a full-blown fuzz-guitar freakout that makes the song sound beautifully nuts.

With its sense of invention, dynamics that keep things interesting throughout and a refreshing knack for songcraft, The End of That is the most optimistic of new beginnings.

Rating: 4.5 out of 5

--Bernard Perusse, Postmedia News

--

The Cranberries

Roses

(Gold Lake/Universal)

Rather than pick up where they left off before their hiatus, the Cranberries were apparently more interested in returning to where they began. This is good news for anyone who prefers the dreamy melancholy of 1993's Everybody Else Is Doing It, So Why Can't We? over the bombast that ruled some of the quartet's later albums. There's hit potential in the buoyant "Tomorrow" and "Show Me's" earnest chorus, but the former is characterized by spirited acoustic guitar and the latter by restless strings. Like the dialed-down arrangements, Dolores O'Riordan's vocals offer merciful relief. A more compelling singer at low volume, she has sworn off her strident yelps, although her lyrics continue to stumble across the division between directness and laziness. (Incredibly, "when we get along / we're really strong" isn't the album's dodgiest couplet.)

Rating: 3 out of 5

--Jordan Zivitz, Postmedia News

--

Dirty Ghosts

Metal Moon

(Last Gang Records)

Allyson Baker sings with the right amount of snarl and spit to remind you of the heyday of Elastica, and the rhythm section of bassist Carson Banks, drummer Michael Urbano and programmer Aesop Rock ensures that the beats are razor sharp and pounding. Essentially a power trio with producer in tow, this is meticulously crafted music that certainly doesn't follow any of the prevailing trends of the moment but certainly deserves the buzz it is generating online. Undeniably reminiscent of the late '80s/early '90s with its frequent reggae baselines and angular hooks, the 10 tracks don't ever disappoint but they sound familiar enough that they don't totally catch fire either.

Rating: 3 out of 5

--Stuart Derdeyn, Postmedia News
